author: By John Koblin
title: The TV Hit That Wasn’t
description: There was a lot of advance hype for the FX series “Impeachment: American Crime Story.” But it won’t be available on any major streaming platform for another 10 months, and that’s a problem in 2021.
content: It was one of the most dramatic episodes of the season. Monica Lewinsky, the heroine of “Impeachment: American Crime Story,” strikes an immunity deal with federal prosecutors, and President Bill Clinton admits to having had an affair to a grand jury and the nation as a whole. The episode also brought Hillary Clinton, portrayed by Edie Falco, to center stage for the first time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage
title: Here’s what the Texas law prohibits.
description: Abortions are now illegal in Texas after “cardiac activity” is detectable, usually at around six weeks of pregnancy.
content: The Texas law, known as Senate Bill 8, bars abortions once “cardiac activity” can be detected in an embryo. Such activity consists of electrical pulses that can be picked up on ultrasound but are not yet true heartbeats, since heart valves form later in the process of embryonic development.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley, Lisa Friedman and Somini Sengupta
title: Leaders Warn of Climate ‘Doomsday’ as Old Rifts Divide Summit’s First Day
description: The opening day of a climate summit was heavy on dire warnings and light on substantive proposals as leaders in Glasgow met to discuss a warming world.
content: GLASGOW — World leaders opened a pivotal climate summit in Scotland on Monday with apocalyptic warnings about the scarce time left to avert catastrophic global warming, yet offered few new commitments to more aggressively cut greenhouse gas emissions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Priya Krishna
title: Live at La Grenouille: Caviar, Crystal and the Owner’s Flashy Crooning
description: This once-tranquil Midtown shrine of formal French dining has a new feel, as Philippe Masson prowls the floor (and tabletops) in a vigorous jazz act.
content: Around 9:15 on a recent Wednesday evening, the mood in the full but otherwise serene dining room of La Grenouille suddenly shifted.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Stephen Gandel, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Why Jeffrey Epstein Cost Barclays’s C.E.O. His Job
description: British regulators had examined what Jes Staley told his bank’s board about ties to the disgraced financier.
content: Barclays announced this morning that Jes Staley had stepped down as C.E.O. after he and its board learned of the results of a two-year investigation by British regulators into his ties to Jeffrey Epstein. This makes Staley the latest business leader to face repercussions from their association with the convicted sex offender.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Marc Hearron, attorney for abortion providers, has deep Texas ties.
description: Mr. Hearron has worked on pro bono cases involving reproductive rights and L.G.B.T.Q. rights.
content: Abortion clinics and providers challenging the Texas anti-abortion law will be represented before the Supreme Court on Monday by Marc Hearron, senior counsel for the Center for Reproductive Rights.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Will Justice Brett Kavanaugh change his position?
description: Justice Kavanaugh has consistently supported abortion restrictions, but occasionally stakes out more moderate positions than his colleagues.
content: Justice Brett M. Kavanaugh, who voted with the majority in September to allow the Texas law to come into effect, may be the member of the court most open to switching sides on the issue. Though his voting record in abortion cases has consistently supported abortion restrictions, he has made occasional comments staking out more moderate positions than those of his colleagues.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ephrat Livni and Eric Lipton
title: Regulators Ask Congress to Create New Rules for Cryptocurrencies
description: A Treasury Department report says stablecoin issuers should operate like banks to avoid destabilizing runs that could erode financial stability.
content: WASHINGTON — Federal regulators say they urgently need more power from Congress to properly regulate stablecoins, a fast-growing type of cryptocurrency that they warn could result in bank runs, consumer abuse and payment snafus unless lawmakers act quickly, according to a report issued Monday by the Treasury Department.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reed Abelson
title: Biden Promised to Fix Home Care for Seniors. Much More Help May Be Needed.
description: The latest Democratic proposal would funnel $150 billion toward subsidized home and community-based care. Experts worry that may not be enough to ease the severe shortage of workers.
content: Spinal surgery four years ago left Alene Shaheed in a wheelchair and dependent on short daily visits from home health aides to help her get around.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Zimmer
title: The Novavax vaccine, backed by Operation Warp Speed, has won its first authorization — in Indonesia.
description: After months of production delays, this is the first vaccine authorization for Novavax and its manufacturing partner, the Serum Institute of India.
content: Novavax, a Maryland-based company that received $1.75 billion from the United States government to develop a protein-based Covid-19 vaccine, announced Monday it had won emergency authorization for its vaccine in Indonesia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noel Murray
title: ‘Succession’ Season 3, Episode 3: Head Spaces and Hullabaloo
description: There was plenty of petty Roy cruelty to go around in this week’s brutal episode.
content: “Succession” is often a “fun” show, where all the sniping and the slip-ups of the rich and the arrogant generate some incredibly entertaining schadenfreude. But any given episode — like this week’s “The Disruption” — can be brutal, as the characters we hate to love fall hard.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane E. Brody
title: Are Too Many Older Adults Told They Have Kidney Disease?
description: Many men and women with “failing kidneys” may not have anything more than a normal age-related decline in kidney function.
content: If the public has learned anything about medicine during the Covid-19 pandemic, it is that science is constantly evolving. New findings can change how experts define a given illness, as well as how they diagnose, prevent and treat it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: A Preserves Maker Turns to Tea
description: Bonne Maman now carries five herbal tea blends, perfect with a scone slathered in preserves.
content: Bonne Maman, a popular maker of preserves and jellies, has added herbal teas to its inventory. It also uses “wellness” as a selling point with each variety supposedly devised to bring delight, vitality, serenity and so forth, something that has become de rigueur for many products. These teas don’t need it; they’re lovely enough on their own and they all induce pleasure. There are five blends, each a mix of ingredients like lemon verbena, lavender, elderflower, star anise, peppermint, licorice, lemongrass, yarrow, cranberry and the like, and, depending on the ingredients, each has a dominant flavor like lemon, anise or mint coming through.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ximena Casas
title: How the ‘Green Wave’ Movement Did the Unthinkable in Latin America
description: A sisterhood of activists achieved success with aggressive tactics, but big challenges remain.
content: While access to safe abortion is threatened from the United States to China, the “Marea Verde,” or Green Wave, women’s movement has helped deliver groundbreaking reforms and progress on reproductive health and rights in Latin America.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: Jurors Who Convicted Derek Chauvin Are Identified for First Time
description: A judge also released questionnaires that the jurors had filled out before they were selected for the trial, which ended with Mr. Chauvin being imprisoned for murdering George Floyd.
content: MINNEAPOLIS — More than six months after a jury found the former Minneapolis police officer Derek Chauvin guilty of murdering George Floyd, the identities of the 12 jurors whose verdict sent Mr. Chauvin to prison were released on Monday for the first time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: How Often Do Covid Vaccines Cause Heart Problems in Kids?
description: The latest data is reassuring. Myocarditis remains very uncommon, and it is almost always mild and temporary. The heart risk from Covid-19 itself is far greater.
content: Federal regulators are reviewing data on the link between Moderna’s coronavirus vaccine and a rare heart problem in adolescents, the company announced on Sunday. That side effect — myocarditis, an inflammation of the heart muscle — has also worried advisers to federal agencies in deliberations regarding use of the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine in younger children and teenagers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joseph Goldstein, Ashley Southall and Emma G. Fitzsimmons
title: N.Y.C.’s vaccination rate for city workers climbs to 91 percent, and 9,000 are put on unpaid leave.
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio said the city was running smoothly despite the absences, and urged workers to get vaccinated and return to work.
content: New York City started to enforce its Covid vaccine mandate for municipal workers on Monday, and about 9,000 workers who refused to get vaccinated were placed on unpaid leave.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noam Scheiber
title: How the Pandemic Has Added to Labor Unrest
description: While big companies wield considerable power, Covid’s economic disruption has given workers new leverage, contributing to a recent upturn in strikes.
content: When 420 workers at the Heaven Hill spirits bottling plant near Louisville went on strike in September, they were frustrated that the company’s proposed contract could reduce their overtime pay. Many had earned extra income working seven days a week during the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian M. Rosenthal
title: N.Y. Cabbies Stage Hunger Strike for More Aid: ‘We’re Not Backing Down’
description: After exploitative loans buried taxi drivers under crushing debt, some cabbies say the city’s $65 million rescue package does not go far enough.
content: When Mayor Bill de Blasio announced in March a plan to spend tens of millions of dollars to help New York’s taxi drivers, many praised the move. For years, officials had stood by as cabbies were channeled into exploitative loans that crushed them under mountains of debt. Finally, it seemed, the city was fixing an injustice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘Sway'
title: Sex Bots, Religion and the Wild World of A.I.
description: The writer Jeanette Winterson explores the wild world unfolding alongside the rise of artificial intelligence.
content: As Tesla develops its humanoid robot and Facebook — sorry, now Meta — rebrands to signal its focus on the metaverse and an even more virtual world, some might continue to wonder whether an Armageddon that will have artificial intelligence overpowering humans is a possibility. But the novelist Jeanette Winterson is more optimistic. Her more utopian view of an A.I.-enabled future depends on more compassionate technologies and the diversification of the leaders driving innovation, who she says are currently “rich guys with a lot of power, and we can’t depend on their benevolence.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Victor
title: David Attenborough urges summit participants to help ‘rewrite our story.’
description: “If working apart we are force powerful enough to destabilize our planet,” the naturalist said, “surely working together we are powerful enough to save it.”
content: David Attenborough, one of Britain’s most trusted public figures and among the world’s most recognizable voices for Earth’s natural beauty, implored leaders to use the COP26 summit as a climate turning point, creating a more equitable world in the process.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roy Furchgott
title: Can Supersonic Air Travel Fly Again?
description: The key to its revival may be a breakthrough in creating a quieter sonic boom. The challenges, though, are significant.
content: Despite the promise of two-hour flights from New York to Los Angeles, the supersonic airline industry never really got off the ground. That is largely because of physics: specifically, the sonic boom, the thunderclap noise made when an aircraft breaks the sound barrier, which essentially doomed supersonic aviation as a viable business.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles V. Bagli
title: Robert Durst Charged With 2nd-Degree Murder in His Wife’s Disappearance
description: Mr. Durst, who was sentenced to life in prison in California two weeks ago, now faces another trial in New York.
content: Kathie McCormack Durst, the young wife of a real estate scion, returned to the couple’s weekend cottage in South Salem, N.Y., on the evening of Jan. 31, 1982, and after yet another argument with her husband, she vanished.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: Deciding the future of the climate.
content: Presidents and prime ministers are gathering in Glasgow this week for the 12-day U.N. global warming conference, often referred to as COP26, to discuss global climate policies, which are likely to determine the future of the planet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jay Caspian Kang
title: A Quietly Big Idea on How We Think About Homeless People
description: Should housing status be a protected category like race, gender or religion?
content: Are the unhoused a “people”? If the answer is yes, then don’t they deserve equal protection under the law? These questions were broached last week by the American Civil Liberties Union of Southern California in a lengthy report titled “Outside the Law: The Legal War Against Unhoused People.” Rather than think of homelessness as a condition, the authors argue, lawmakers should protect those who live on the street in the same way that the Constitution and California law protect groups based on race, gender or religion. The report calls for “state legislation prohibiting discrimination based on housing status.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Bradsher
title: China’s push to burn more coal puts climate goals at risk.
description: China, the world’s biggest user of fossil fuels, has taken big steps in recent days to address the global energy shortage this fall and to fight inflation, but the moves come at considerable cost to efforts to halt climate change.
content: China, the world’s biggest user of fossil fuels, has taken big steps in recent days to address the global energy shortage this fall and to fight inflation, but the moves come at considerable cost to efforts to halt climate change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang, Niki Kitsantonis, Richard C. Paddock, Muktita Suhartono and Daniel E. Slotnik
title: Some Australians are allowed to return home as border rules ease.
description: After 18 months of strict measures to combat the pandemic, the states of New South Wales and Victoria relaxed restrictions on citizens and permanent residents seeking to travel back from overseas.
content: After being separated from his parents for two years, Jimmy Sugandi, 42, touched down on Monday in Melbourne, Australia, after traveling from Indonesia with his wife and two young children.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Rodney Reed Should Not Be Retried in Texas Murder Case, Judge Says
description: The judge said that new evidence, including witness testimony, was not sufficient to warrant a new trial for Mr. Reed, who was sentenced to death in the 1996 murder of a 19-year-old woman.
content: A judge in Texas has recommended that Rodney Reed, a death row prisoner whose case has drawn the attention of celebrities and elected officials, should not receive a new trial in the 1996 murder of a 19-year-old woman.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: I Just Turned 60, but I Still Feel 22
description: Sorrow in the face of aging would be a poor response to this good fortune.
content: NASHVILLE — I was already in college before I finally understood that my entire life had overlapped with second-wave feminism, a force that transformed American culture without so much as registering on a certain young woman in Alabama. All my life I had been stepping through open doors, it turned out, blithely unaware of the vision and sacrifice and passionate persistence of the women who had opened those doors for me.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Friskics-Warren
title: Ronnie Tutt, 83, Dies; Powerful Drummer Backed Rock and Pop Stars
description: He was a force in Elvis Presley’s TCB band and accompanied other big names like Jerry Garcia, Billy Joel and Elvis Costello.
content: NASHVILLE — Ronnie Tutt, the prolific and versatile drummer who accompanied both Elvises, Presley and Costello, as well as other major figures in rock and pop like Jerry Garcia and Neil Diamond, died on Oct. 16 at his home in Franklin, Tenn. He was 83.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Daniels
title: What Is a Meaningful Family Relationship That You Have?
description: Why is this person special to you?
content: In “Kuya,” an illustrated piece by the artist AJ Dungo, he tells the story of his relationship with his older brother, who struggles with mental illness. He is proud of his brother’s courage, and he sees far beyond any negative labels that society might put on his brother.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: Shopping for Alarm Clocks
description: Because it’s the time of year when we could all use a little extra help waking up.
content: With clocks being set back Sunday, at the end of daylight saving time, it will be hard to deny that winter is on the way, and many of us may feel temporarily out of sorts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Noble Maillard
title: Fry Bread Is Beloved, but Also Divisive
description: For Indigenous people, the dish is both a family comfort food and a relic of colonial displacement.
content: Art Coulson, a Cherokee writer who lives in Minneapolis, took a deep breath before he tried to define Native American fry bread.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyson Krueger
title: Can’t. Stop. Self-Swabbing.
description: At-home Covid tests are providing (occasionally obsessive) assurance ahead of dates, baby visits and weddings.
content: When Matt Reardon noticed a certain bachelor party favor disappearing, one that “definitely added to the fun of the weekend,” he took note.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Somini Sengupta
title: Narendra Modi says India will sharply increase renewable energy.
description: Wealthy nations need to spend $1 trillion to help developing nations like India make the transition to renewables, Prime Minister Modi said.
content: India announced on Monday that it would significantly expand renewable energy sources in its total energy mix and called on the rich world to pony up $1 trillion to help developing countries make the energy transition.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Coscarelli
title: Drake Earns a Fifth Week at No. 1 Ahead of Music’s Major Fall Releases
description: With new albums by Ed Sheeran, Taylor Swift and Adele looming, the rapper’s “Certified Lover Boy” remains atop the Billboard chart.
content: Before Ed Sheeran, Taylor Swift and Adele make themselves known on the Billboard album chart, there is still Drake.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Why a Pilot Is Under Investigation for Saying ‘Let’s Go Brandon’
description: His remarks went viral after he repeated the chant, which is understood to be code for swearing at President Biden, during a Southwest Airlines flight.
content: It began as a chant at a NASCAR race. It became an inside joke among many Republicans that spread to T-shirts and even to the floor of Congress. And now it has entangled Southwest Airlines in the nation’s political tussles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrés R. Martínez and Ethan Hauser
title: What to watch for on Monday at COP26.
description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson was first to welcome leaders, who will then lay out “concrete actions and credible plans.” David Attenborough and Prince Charles are also speaking.
content: The next two days of the United Nations-led climate talks in Glasgow will be an opportunity to hear from nearly 100 heads of state and governments on what steps they plan to take to tackle climate change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder and James Wagner
title: A Grand Slam Wasted, Atlanta Is Left Holding Its Breath
description: Adam Duvall’s blast felt like the where-were-you-when moment Atlanta has been seeking for decades. And then it wasn’t.
content: ATLANTA — Of course, it was too easy. Here, it almost always is.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: A World Series of Relievers, Like It or Not
description: Injuries have forced things to extremes for both Houston and Atlanta, with bullpens accounting for more than 60 percent of all innings pitched. This was not by design.
content: ATLANTA — Greg Maddux leads all living people in major league victories, with 355. He tossed the ceremonial first pitch before Game 5 of the World Series on Sunday at Truist Park. Tucker Davidson is tied with roughly 7.8 billion other people for last place in major league victories, with zero. He threw the first pitch that counted.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Steinhauer
title: Desperate for Housing Options, Communities Turn to Ballot Initiatives
description: Cities and counties will vote on measures, like tax increases and curbs on Airbnb, aimed at creating more affordable housing.
content: LEADVILLE, Colo. — A small-business owner in a town fueled by vacationers is an unconventional proponent for a tax increase on tourists. But Marcee Lundeen sees few other choices.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Armstrong
title: After the Flood, It’s Not Just ‘About the Coming Back’
description: Following the devastation wrought by Hurricane Ida in Millburn, N.J., small business owners are facing an uncertain future, even as the community rallies to help.
content: MILLBURN, N.J. — To survive the pandemic’s waves, Kevin Cao, the owner of Thai House Restaurant, halted dine-in service, cut five staff members and kept his drunken noodles, pad thai and curry moving with curbside pickup and delivery.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benedict Carey
title: Dr. Aaron T. Beck, Developer of Cognitive Therapy, Dies at 100
description: It was an answer to Freudian analysis: a pragmatic, thought-monitoring approach to treating anxiety, depression and other mental disorders, and it changed psychiatry.
content: Dr. Aaron T. Beck, whose brand of pragmatic, thought-monitoring psychotherapy became the centerpiece of a scientific transformation in the treatment of depression, anxiety and many related mental disorders, died on Monday at his home in Philadelphia. He was 100.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: An Uncommon Rise for Bread
description: Jenny Bardwell explains how to salt-rise bread in a virtual talk for the Culinary Historians of New York.
content: The pandemic gave rise to a passion for sourdough among countless home bakers. But how many of them tackled the possibly more finicky salt-rising technique for bread, an American tradition that dates back to 18th century Appalachia? It’s not too late to learn. A Zoom event organized by the Culinary Historians of New York and led by Jenny Bardwell, a Culinary Institute of America graduate and a scholar of salt-rising, will explore the topic. Ms. Bardwell, who wrote “Salt-Rising Bread: Recipes and Heartfelt Stories of a Nearly Lost Appalachian Tradition” with Susan Ray Brown, will be baking bread in her kitchen in Pennsylvania during the talk. She also plans to discuss salt-rising in other countries, including Greece.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik
title: The official global virus death toll has passed five million. The full count is undoubtedly higher.
description: Many countries do not accurately report their figures, and many Covid deaths are misattributed, experts say.
content: The coronavirus is responsible for more than five million confirmed deaths around the world as of Monday, according to data from the Center for Systems Science and Engineering at Johns Hopkins University. Such a loss would wipe out almost the entire population of Melbourne, Australia, or most of the nation of Singapore.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: One Final Day of Campaigning
description: The elections for mayor in New York City and Buffalo could signal the direction of the Democratic Party in the state.
content: It’s Monday. We’ll take a last look at the campaigns and the candidates. Did I mention that tomorrow is Election Day?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Asimov
title: The Accidental Wine Educator
description: Over the last 50 years, America has become the world’s leading wine consumer. Kevin Zraly has had a lot to do with that.
content: The history of wine in the United States owes a lot to something of a happy accident.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: Traveling the World for Recipes, but Always Looking for Home
description: Famous for her scholarly works, the cookbook author Claudia Roden shows off her lyrical side with her latest, “Claudia Roden’s Mediterranean.”
content: LONDON — If you’ve ever swiped a supple piece of pita bread through a plate of garlicky hummus and your family roots aren’t in the Middle East, you may have Claudia Roden to thank.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: How to Prevent Climate Disasters
description: World leaders are in Glasgow.
content: The world has made more progress combating climate change than you may realize.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage
title: What is Ex Parte Young, much-discussed in the Texas abortion case?
description: The 1908 case held that state officials could be sued in federal court to prevent them from enforcing unconstitutional laws.
content: As the Supreme Court struggled on Monday with whether it could or should block Texas courts from hearing lawsuits by private citizens against abortion providers under the state’s novel anti-abortion law, a 1908 case called Ex Parte Young kept coming up.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck
title: What Does It Mean to Be a New York Democrat These Days?
description: A series of Election Day contests may serve as a barometer of how far left Democratic voters in New York State want their party to go.
content: Last November, the often-fractious Democrats of New York papered over their sharp differences to celebrate Donald Trump’s defeat, a development that briefly united the party’s relatively moderate leader, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, with the state’s ascendant left wing.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: On the Left, a New Scramble Over the Right Words to Say
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, November 1, 2021.
content: “When you’ve been on the margin, being able to claim a language and a narrative and a set of words to express yourself is incredibly important.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abdi Latif Dahir and Ismail Alfa
title: Nigeria Building Collapse Kills at Least 5 With Many More Trapped
description: As many as 100 workers were feared trapped at a construction site in Lagos, where building collapses are common, with contractors using shoddy materials and regulations often not enforced.
content: NAIROBI, Kenya — A 21-story building under construction crumbled on Monday in Lagos, Nigeria’s financial capital and Africa’s largest city, leaving what workers said were as many as 100 construction workers trapped and at least five dead in the latest structural failure in a rapidly expanding metropolis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor and Valerie Hopkins
title: Queen Elizabeth, calling for statesmanship, not politics, said ‘the time for action’ is now.
description: The 95-year-old monarch gave her address by video, after doctors advised her to rest and not go to the summit. Prince Charles attended and delivered a similar message.
content: Queen Elizabeth II, absent from the climate summit because of health concerns but not silent, urged world leaders on Monday to rise above their current political differences and show true statesmanship for the sake of the planet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Salman Masood
title: After Violent Standoff, Pakistan Strikes Deal With Banned Islamist Group
description: The pact, announced Sunday, defused a crisis that had paralyzed several cities, but it also highlighted the government’s struggle to assert itself against religious extremists.
content: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Pakistan averted a political showdown on Monday as officials reopened a key national highway that supporters of a militant Islamist group had occupied for days, following a secret pact between the government and the group.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Winkler
title: If the New Supreme Court Stymies Gun Safety Laws, What Comes Next?
description: If gun safety activists want their agenda to survive, they will have to stop trying to ban guns — and focus instead on reducing the violence  those guns bring.
content: The gun safety movement finds itself on the precipice of disaster.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: Stopping Climate Change Doesn’t Need to Be Altruistic
description: A proposal to share the gains evenly between nations and generations.
content: One of the approximately 700 things that make climate change a knotty problem is that fighting it requires people living today to do things for the benefit of future generations. And, you know, what have future generations ever done for us?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyssa Lukpat and Marc Santora
title: Greta Thunberg joins a protest in Glasgow.
description: The activist, whose solo climate strikes in 2018 helped fuel a youth climate movement, was greeted like a rock star upon arriving in the city, according to videos.
content: As Greta Thunberg joined scores of protesters on the streets outside the United Nations climate conference in Glasgow on Monday, an online petition that she helped start quickly drew more than a million signatures.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: Audra McDonald to Star in ‘Ohio State Murders’ on Broadway
description: The production brings the world of the playwright Adrienne Kennedy, 90, to Broadway for the first time.
content: The actress Audra McDonald has agreed to star in a Broadway production of “Ohio State Murders,” bringing the work of the eminent experimental playwright Adrienne Kennedy to the nation’s most prominent stage for the first time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: The Recipe for Coming Back From a 3-1 Deficit? It Varies.
description: The Houston Astros are trying to pull off a feat that has been done only six times in the World Series. Players from the teams that did it happily recalled their thrilling comebacks.
content: HOUSTON — In the somber moments after the Pittsburgh Pirates lost Game 4 of the 1979 World Series to the Baltimore Orioles to fall behind three games to one, Willie Stargell spoke to his teammates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sandra E. Garcia
title: ‘Insecure’ Recap, Season 5, Episode 2: Pick Up Your Feelings
description: Busy with their careers and friendship, Issa and Molly forget to turn back to themselves.
content: In the last episode of “Insecure,” we left Molly and Issa intentionally thrusting themselves forward in life. The ladies decided to move past their tiff. They stopped relying on exes and pining for past versions of themselves.
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: Nov. 1, 2021
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Nov. 1, 2021.
content: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Shannon
title: Climate Summit, Virus Deaths, Abortion: Your Monday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas L. Friedman
title: Would Russia or China Help Us if We Were Invaded by Space Aliens?
description: We now face a similar, world-stressing threat from a much more familiar and once seemingly benign force: our climate.
content: In a recent essay on great-power competition and climate change, Rob Litwak, an arms control expert at the Wilson Center, recalled a question that President Ronald Reagan posed to Mikhail Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, after they took a walk during their 1985 Lake Geneva summit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage
title: Why is it so hard to challenge the Texas law?
description: The structure of the law, which delegates enforcement authority to millions of people, means there is no obvious person whom its opponents can sue.
content: It is hard to challenge the Texas law because it was written in a novel way: It effectively deputizes private citizens to enforce it, and bans the state government from doing so.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dashiell Young-Saver
title: Run the Numbers: Exploring the Math Behind Any N.F.L. Team’s Playoff Chances
description: In this lesson, students use math, probability and computer simulations to estimate their N.F.L. team’s chances of playing in the postseason.
content: Featured article: “2021 N.F.L. Playoff Picture: Every Team’s Playoff Chances”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse McKinley
title: India Walton Beat Byron Brown in Buffalo. He’s Back With a Rubber Stamp.
description: A victory in the Buffalo mayor’s race on Tuesday by Ms. Walton would make history on several fronts. The incumbent mayor, Mr. Brown, has mounted a write-in campaign against her.
content: BUFFALO, N.Y. — If Byron Brown succeeds in his frantic quest for a fifth term as mayor of Buffalo, he may well have a rubber stamp to thank.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Flitter
title: Banks Tried to Kill Crypto and Failed. Now They’re Embracing It (Slowly).
description: Digital payments technology is forcing the financial system to evolve. Banks feel their power waning and want to regain control.
content: In 2014, as regulators in New York were exploring ways to control Bitcoin, executives at Wall Street’s biggest banks fretted that regulating cryptocurrencies would also legitimize them — and that could threaten the finance industry. So they tried to sow doubt.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ashley Wong
title: The Best Places to Watch the New York City Marathon
description: It has become the city’s biggest block party. Here’s where to cheer for the 30,000 runners in every borough.
content: The New York City Marathon, one of the world’s largest marathons, is back. This year’s race will be smaller, with 30,000 runners instead of the usual 55,000. But it is expected to be a major, and emotional, milestone in New York’s recovery from the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Somini Sengupta
title: The U.N. leader warns that the world faces a ‘climate catastrophe.’
description: He urged countries to review their climate pledges annually rather than every five years as called for in the 2015 Paris accord.
content: The United Nations secretary general, António Guterres, on Monday issued a blistering critique of the world’s failure to rein in global warming, calling on countries to return every year to review their climate targets — not every five years, as the Paris climate agreement spells out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley
title: Biden calls for tougher action on emissions and promises job gains worldwide.
description: “We have only a brief window” to avoid the most disastrous effects of global warming, President Biden warned at the United Nations climate summit.
content: President Biden told world leaders on Monday that “we only have a brief window before us to raise our ambitions” to fight climate change, warning that climate disasters were already imposing trillions of dollars of economic costs but offering hope that a shift to lower-emission energy sources could create millions of jobs around the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman
title: Climate conference kicks off in Glasgow with floods and low expectations.
description: GLASGOW — The first day of climate talks got off to a rocky start.
content: GLASGOW — The first day of climate talks got off to a rocky start.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Olivia Waite
title: Choose Me! Rose-worthy Romance Novels
description: This month’s column includes two books set in the funhouse-mirror world of reality TV and another that takes place in the Alaskan wilderness.
content: We will never reach a general sense of how realistic — or unrealistic — the romance genre is because with romance, every generalization is a trap. Some people will confidently tell you that romance novels are old-fashioned tools of the patriarchy; other people will just as confidently explain that romance is innately progressive and feminist.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Goldberg
title: We Should All Know Less About Each Other
description: On social media, exposure to those unlike us often makes us hate them.
content: In 2017, after the shock of Brexit and then Donald Trump’s election, Christopher Bail, a professor of sociology and public policy at Duke University, set out to study what would happen if you forced people out of their social media echo chambers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joey Roulette
title: Amazon to Launch First Two Internet Satellites in 2022
description: Competing with SpaceX, OneWeb and others, the e-commerce titan will rely on small rockets to get prototypes of its satellite constellation into space.
content: Amazon is getting ready to go to space.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: No, Vaccine Mandates Aren’t an Attack on Freedom
description: It's hard to imagine a worse case for defending personal choice.
content: The Delta surge in Covid-19 seems to be receding. That’s good news, and not just because fewer people are dying. Fear of infection was one reason the economic recovery hit an air pocket in the third quarter. Resuming normal life will be a huge relief.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: MONDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley and Lisa Friedman
title: Even as Biden Pushes Clean Energy, He Seeks More Oil Production
description: President Biden acknowledged “it seems like an irony” that he is asking energy-rich nations to boost oil production as he implores the world to tackle climate change.
content: GLASGOW — President Biden told a global climate summit on Monday that “we only have a brief window before us” to reduce the emissions from burning oil, gas and coal that pose an “existential threat” to humanity. But only days earlier, he was urging the world’s largest oil producers to pump more of the fossil fuels that are warming the planet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: Changing of the Guard at Williamstown Theater Festival
description: Mandy Greenfield has resigned and Jenny Gersten will be interim artistic director. The festival gave no reason for the move, but it follows complaints about working conditions.
content: The artistic director of the prestigious Williamstown Theater Festival has stepped down after complaints by some employees about working conditions there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Hints That It May Allow Challenge to Texas Abortion Law
description: In two arguments on Monday, the justices considered challenges from abortion providers and the Biden administration to a law that bans abortions after about six weeks.
content: WASHINGTON — After almost three hours of lively arguments on Monday at the Supreme Court, a majority of the justices seemed inclined to allow abortion providers — but perhaps not the Biden administration — to pursue a federal court challenge to a Texas law that has sharply curtailed abortions in the state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael J. de la Merced and Matthew Goldstein
title: James Staley, Barclays’s C.E.O., steps down after a Jeffrey Epstein inquiry.
description: British regulators investigated how the bank executives characterized his ties with the disgraced financier.
content: More than two years after Jeffrey Epstein was found dead in a Manhattan jail cell, the consequences of associating with the convicted sex offender continue to reverberate through the highest echelons of the business world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Muriel Lezak, Leading Authority on Brain Injuries, Dies at 94
description: A neuropsychologist, she wrote a textbook that became an essential guide to describing and evaluating brain damage and dysfunction.
content: Muriel Lezak, a neuropsychologist who wrote a landmark textbook in the early days of her discipline that became an essential guide to the description and evaluation of brain injuries and disorders, died on Oct. 6 in a memory care facility in Portland, Ore. She was 94.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mimi Vu
title: A Nourishing Filipino-Inspired Soup for Fall
description: To celebrate the publication of ‘Filipinx,’ their new cookbook, the chef Angela Dimayuga and the writer Ligaya Mishan made nilaga.
content: The chef Angela Dimayuga grew up in San Jose, Calif., the fifth of six children in a Filipino American family, and still remembers the slowly simmering soups and stews that seemed to be constantly bubbling away in the kitchen of her childhood home. Because both of her parents worked — her mother as an administrator for IBM and Intel, her father as a manager at McDonald’s — her mother would often cook a week’s worth of food at once. One of her standbys was nilaga, a simple yet flavorful soup of slow-braised beef shanks, bone marrow and earthy vegetables. “Nilaga was something we had on regular rotation because it’s nourishing and could feed a lot of us,” says Dimayuga, 36, who, until recently, was the creative director of food and culture for the Standard hotels. “It’s an easy dish to make, since it’s all passive cooking: You throw the meat in with some water.” Come dinnertime, the family would gather around the huge pots, ladling steaming broth, marrow bones and fragrant rice into their bowls before crowding together to eat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: Neal Brennan Thinks Auteurs Can Still Make Chipotle Commercials
description: The comedian-producer, whose latest solo show opens in Manhattan, discusses déjà vu from ‘Grand Theft Auto’ and the cringe-y candor of Kanye West.
content: A few years ago, Neal Brennan went to see the illusionist Derek DelGaudio’s hit show “In & Of Itself” and selected a card that said “comedian” to describe himself, out of the hundreds on offer. The show ends with DelGaudio guessing what every audience member has chosen. When Brennan’s turn came, DelGaudio said, “You’re a very good comedian.” “I was like, ‘OK, that’s cute,’” Brennan said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giulia Heyward
title: Judd Stone II, the Texas solicitor general, makes his Supreme Court debut.
description: Stone is a former clerk to Justice Antonin Scalia and former chief counsel to Senator Ted Cruz.
content: Judd Stone II, a former clerk to the conservative Supreme Court Justice Antonin Scalia, was named solicitor general of Texas earlier this year. On Monday, he will take on his most high-profile challenge to date: arguing before the Supreme Court on behalf of the state in two challenges to its new anti-abortion law.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kathryn Kolbert and Julie F. Kay
title: Roe Is as Good as Gone. It’s Time for a New Strategy.
description: Abortion-right supporters need to stop banging our heads against the Supreme Court’s marble walls.
content: For the first time in a generation, the Supreme Court appears likely to overturn Roe v. Wade. The end of Roe need not herald the end of an era of reproductive freedom. It may instead launch a new strategy that protects the fundamental human right to decide whether to have children and raise them in safety and dignity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: Once a Leading Polluter, the U.K. Is Now Trying to Lead on Climate Change
description: On the eve of a global climate summit, Britain’s evolution from fossil fuels to clean energy is on display. But experts question whether its commitment is sufficient, and whether it can persuade other nations to meet meaningful goals.
content: LONDON — As Britain prepares to host a landmark climate summit in Glasgow this week, the milestones of its own evolution to a more climate-friendly economy are on vivid display along the railroad line from London to Scotland.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: A 6-Hour Opera in a Pandemic? The Met Goes for It.
description: As some try to lure audiences back with short programs, the Metropolitan Opera is staging its longest work: Wagner’s “Die Meistersinger.”
content: As cultural institutions come back to life this fall after the long pandemic shutdown, many are trying to lure audiences back with shorter shows, often free of intermissions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Peking Duck With Added Fire
description: Hutong has added a flaming Peking duck to its menu in limited supply.
content: At its locations in Hong Kong Dubai, Hutong has been serving flaming Peking duck. Now the newly reopened dining room of the lavish restaurant chain’s New York branch also offers the glistening duck licked with blue fire tableside. More than mere floor show, the duck is seasoned with a chile-forward marinade. The flaming is said to impart extra crispness to the skin. Regardless, it is delicious, a whole well-burnished duck expertly carved, presented with accouterments, including sauces other than hoisin, and enough to serve four, $116. A second course is made with the meat left after slicing, minced with vegetables in a lettuce wrap, for a dish that’s more Cantonese than Beijing. As of now only five flaming ducks are available a night Monday through Thursday evenings to book in advance. The fireworks will be coming to the restaurant chain’s Miami location soon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lily Geismer and Eitan D. Hersh
title: Laugh at the ‘S.N.L.’ School Board Skit, Take Your Local Politics Seriously
description: If you’re tired of politics as usual, give local democracy a chance.
content: Angry activists have commandeered so many routine school board meetings in the past few months that “Saturday Night Live” — which typically reserves its political satire for politicians on the national stage — recently devoted a segment to satirizing one of these raucous meetings. Less humorously, Attorney General Merrick Garland has launched a push to address the nationwide uptick in violent threats against school board members, teachers and public school workers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane, Jonathan Weisman and Margot Sanger-Katz
title: Manchin Raises Doubts on Safety Net Bill, Complicating Path to Quick Vote
description: Senator Joe Manchin III of West Virginia, a crucial Democratic swing vote, demanded more time to evaluate the economic and fiscal impact of the $1.85 trillion bill.
content: WASHINGTON — Senator Joe Manchin III of West Virginia raised new doubts on Monday about an emerging compromise on a $1.85 trillion climate change and social safety net bill, warning that he had serious reservations about the plan and criticizing liberals in his party for what he called an “all or nothing” stance on it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Stick or Block, This Butter Saver Holds It All
description: Keep a spread always at the ready with these well-designed Butter Hubs.
content: The creators of the Butter Hub have tried to think of everything when it comes to butter storage and have probably succeeded for households that do not mind plastic on the table. It comes with a stainless steel spreader that clings to a magnet on top of the cover; the cover has legs so it sits above the table surface to keep it clean; and inside the base a couple of little ski jumps at either end help remove pats from the knife. The Butter Hub is made in six colors as well as clear, and can fit American quarter-pound sticks or wider, European and Asian (and Plugra) eight-ounce blocks. It’s also dishwasher-safe. There’s an earlier, discounted model that cannot go into the dishwasher.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman, Jim Tankersley and Coral Davenport
title: Biden’s Glasgow pitch: This time, the U.S. is serious about climate change.
description: In Glasgow, President Biden will try to convince a gathering of world leaders that the United States, which has pumped more greenhouse gases into the atmosphere than any other nation, is finally serious about addressing climate change and that others should follow its lead.
content: In Glasgow, President Biden will try to convince a gathering of world leaders that the United States, which has pumped more greenhouse gases into the atmosphere than any other nation, is finally serious about addressing climate change and that others should follow its lead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Tries to Tame Unruly Oral Arguments
description: The court, which is hearing major cases on abortion and guns, has revised its procedures to make sure that all justices are heard.
content: WASHINGTON — Justices Sonia Sotomayor and Clarence Thomas may not agree about much, but they have both said the Supreme Court’s oral arguments have been plagued by too many interruptions. A few years ago and again this fall, the court took steps to address their concerns.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe and Amelia Nierenberg
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: A reporter in South Africa shares her experience with the country’s battle with AIDS.
content: The coronavirus pandemic has now claimed five million lives globally, although experts say that number is almost certainly an undercount. As we pass this bleak milestone, we asked our colleague Lynsey Chutel, based in Johannesburg, to reflect on the legacy of another pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Gary Bettman Defends N.H.L.’s Response to Sexual Abuse Accusation
description: The commissioner spoke publicly to address criticism of the way the league handled a player’s sexual assault accusation against a former Chicago coach.
content: N.H.L. Commissioner Gary Bettman on Monday defended the league’s response to a sexual assault accusation against a former coach.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Jacobs
title: James Ivory, Famous for Buttoned-Up Films, Is Frank About Sex and Much Else in His Memoir
description: “Solid Ivory” is a scrapbook of memories about Ivory’s childhood, his mentors and his filmmaking and romantic partner Ismail Merchant.
content: The movie director James Ivory is most closely associated with decorous period pieces, paeans to inhibition like “Howards End” and “The Remains of the Day,” so I wasn’t expecting his memoirs to be quite such a “Remembrance of Penises Past.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard C. Paddock and Muktita Suhartono
title: Thailand reopens to tourists from 63 countries without requiring quarantine.
description: About a fifth of the nation’s economy depends on the vacation industry. Before the pandemic, the country was one of the world’s top destinations, drawing nearly 40 million visitors in 2019.
content: Thailand reopened on Monday to fully vaccinated tourists arriving by air from 63 countries as it strives to revive its economy despite struggling to reduce Covid-19 case numbers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: Leaders forcefully call for action at COP26.
content: Amid rising seas, more extreme weather and rapidly changing ecosystems, the global climate summit in Glasgow opened on Monday with a series of desperate pleas for action.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Tiny Bubbles on the Walls
description: La Fête du Champagne returns with an immersive experience that takes wine lovers on a journey through how Champagne is made.
content: Last year because of the pandemic there was but a single virtual grand tasting for La Fête du Champagne, the annual extravaganza of tastings and dinners organized by Daniel Johnnes. This year from Saturday through Nov. 14 it has a fuller docket: a mix of Zoom tastings, gala dinners and a major new event — an immersive experience, with participants surrounded by wall projections like the all-encompassing van Gogh exhibits but with Champagne bottles, not sunflowers. Given in 30-minute segments, Nov. 12 through 14 from 2 p.m. to 10 p.m., it will involve traversing several levels of display, a glass of Champagne in hand, $35, at the Lightbox (248 West 37th Street). For the rest of the schedule, the virtual Zoom sessions include two free sessions on Friday, with the rest $25 each with an option to purchase wines for tasting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola
title: New Black N.B.A. Coaches Wonder Why It Took So Long to Get a Shot
description: The N.B.A.’s coaching ranks have long been dominated by white men, but a demand from Black players for more diversity may be changing things.
content: Jamahl Mosley has traveled the world for basketball.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: conflagration
description: This word has appeared in 70 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn Hubler
title: Are Global Warming Summits Still Cool?
description: California’s delegation to the U.N. climate summit won’t include Gov. Gavin Newsom or the state’s last two governors.
content: Few states support climate action as enthusiastically as California. But the Golden State isn’t sending a governor to the United Nations climate change summit this year. Gov. Gavin Newsom is not going, and neither are his predecessors in the office. That’s both unusual and a little telling.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: The Story of a Craft Beer Pioneer
description: “The Dogfish Head Book” by the brewery founders Sam and Mariah Calagione, and written with Andrew C. Greeley, recounts 26 years of beer adventures.
content: Dogfish Head, the brewery founded in 1995 in Rehoboth Beach, Del., by Sam Calagione and his wife, Mariah Calagione, has gone on to become a leading craft brewer releasing dozens of beers each year. Located in Milton, Del., it is now a subsidiary of The Boston Beer Company and has added a distillery, several restaurants and an inn. How a kid kicked out of prep school accomplished it all is the backbone of “The Dogfish Head Book,” a new overstuffed book that chronicles the trajectory. Mr. Calagione went from home-brewed cherry pale ale to a company that produces more than a quarter-million barrels of beer a year. Many of the beers, including the archaeologically researched Midas Touch Ancient Ale, are described in detail, along with comments from fans and employees.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frank Herfort
title: The Stunning Grandeur of Soviet-Era Metros
description: Between 2014 and 2020, Frank Herfort visited more than 770 metro stations in 19 cities, creating a remarkable archive of architectural and artistic splendor.
content: It was a cold day in December 2014, and I was waiting for the train at Shchukinskaya, a station on the Tagansko-Krasnopresnenskaya Line of the Moscow Metro.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Barone
title: Review: ‘Porgy and Bess’ Returns to a New Opera Landscape
description: The Metropolitan Opera’s revival boasts strong performances but raises difficult questions about race and American music.
content: George Gershwin’s “Porgy and Bess” is both easy and impossible to love.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joseph Goldstein and Sharon Otterman
title: 9,000 Unvaccinated N.Y.C. Workers Put on Unpaid Leave as Mandate Begins
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio said thousands more did get the shot and that the first day of the vaccine mandate went smoothly, without significant service disruptions.
content: Hundreds of firefighters called in sick in what appeared to be an organized protest. Sanitation workers were playing catch up, after garbage collection lagged last week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora, Anton Troianovski, Carlotta Gall and Lisa Friedman
title: Who’s attending (Biden and Modi), and who isn’t (Putin and Xi).
description: The presence of heads of state and government is not just symbolic. Real work gets done among leaders that cannot happen among lower-level diplomats.
content: When President Biden was asked in Rome on Sunday about criticism of the world’s wealthiest economies to do more to address climate change, he noted to absence of two key players: China and Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Whitney Bauck
title: Amid Climate Talks, an Actor’s Call to Action Unfolds Onstage
description: A filmed version of Fehinti Balogun’s play about his awakening to climate issues is being shown at the COP26 summit. He is among the theater artists trying to make a difference through their work.
content: The actor Fehinti Balogun knows that theater can mobilize people toward climate action, because that’s what it did for him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hirsch
title: Rivian edges closer to an I.P.O., seeking a valuation above $50 billion.
description: The company updated registration documents with the Securities and Exchange Commission on Monday.
content: Rivian, an electric truck maker backed by Amazon and Ford Motor, is aiming to be valued above $50 billion in its initial public offering next week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Egan
title: 7 Takeaways From Huma Abedin’s Memoir
description: In her new memoir, “Both/And,” Hillary Clinton’s longtime aide opens up about her ex-husband, the 2016 election and more.
content: Toward the end of her new memoir, “Both/And: A Life in Many Worlds,” Huma Abedin recalls what she said to her estranged husband, the former Democratic Representative Anthony Weiner, when the F.B.I. seized his laptop less than two weeks before the 2016 presidential election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee and Nada Rashwan
title: Egypt Poised to Expand Security Powers of President and Military
description: Amendments to a terrorism law will strengthen the grip of the government, just days after it appeared to loosen up by lifting a state of emergency.
content: CAIRO — Egypt is poised to expand the national security powers of the president and military with legislation that will strengthen the hand of the country’s authoritarian government, just as it had appeared to relax its grip last week with the lifting of a longstanding state of emergency.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Miller
title: Facing Elimination, the Houston Astros Find Their Bats
description: A first-inning grand slam had Atlanta thinking championship, but the Astros kept fighting and sent the Series back to Houston for Game 6.
content: ATLANTA — Adam Duvall swung and the baseball sailed high and deep and, surely, toward the history books. The 43,122 Atlanta fans filling Truist Park, early arrivals and in the mood to party with a clinching World Series win within reach, exploded into a raucous din. They believed the grand slam, only the 21st in World Series history, signaled their divine right to celebrate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noel Murray
title: The Best Movies and TV Shows Coming to Amazon, HBO, Hulu and More in November
description: Every month, streaming services add movies and TV shows to its library. Here are our picks for some of November’s most promising new titles.
content: (Note: Streaming services occasionally change schedules without giving notice. For more recommendations on what to stream, sign up for our Watching newsletter here.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: As Youngkin Tries to Finesse Trump, McAuliffe Conjures His Comeback
description: Barnstorming Virginia, the candidates for governor hammered away at their core arguments. For the Republican: parents’ involvement in schools. For the Democrat: Trump redux.
content: FAIRFAX, Va. — In the final hours of campaigning on Monday to become Virginia’s next governor, it was Glenn Youngkin offering an optimistic vision for the future while Terry McAuliffe delivered harsh warnings about ghosts of the past.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Harmon
title: BIPOC or POC? Equity or Equality? The Debate Over Language on the Left.
description: For those pushing for changes in society on race and other issues, words matter. They can also muddle.
content: In California, a Black college freshman from the South is telling a story about his Latino friends from home when he is interrupted by a white classmate. “We say ‘Latinx’ here,” he recalls her saying, using a term he had not heard before, “because we respect trans people.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mitch Smith
title: A judge blocks Chicago from enforcing its vaccine mandate for police officers.
description: The city can require officers to report their vaccination status and be tested, but a Dec. 31 deadline to be vaccinated cannot be enforced until an arbitrator weighs in, the judge ruled.
content: CHICAGO — A judge in Chicago blocked the city on Monday from enforcing a Dec. 31 vaccine mandate for police officers until the issue can be addressed in arbitration. The ruling was a blow to Mayor Lori Lightfoot and a victory for a police union that has been engaged in an increasingly vitriolic battle with City Hall over the rule.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
title: What We’re Watching on Election Day and Movie Night
description: Some politicians we don’t love, some movies we do.
content: Bret Stephens: Hi, Gail. No Republican has won a statewide election in Virginia since 2009. And Joe Biden took the state by more than 10 percentage points last year. But now the polls are showing a dead heat between the Democratic candidate, Terry McAuliffe, and his Republican opponent, Glenn Youngkin, in Tuesday’s race.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liz Alderman
title: Europe Fears That Rising Cost of Climate Action Is Stirring Anger
description: Memories of the Yellow Vest movement are prompting officials to ensure that spiking energy prices don’t fuel inequality or populist discontent.
content: PARIS — Raucous demonstrations against high energy bills in Spain. Demands for social protection in Greece as coal mines close. Fresh protests in French rural areas and small towns over spiking petrol prices.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hirsch
title: The Biden administration will publish vaccine mandate rules ‘in the coming days.’
description: The Labor Department has completed a draft of an emergency standard, which is under review. When it is released, a flurry of corporate vaccine mandates is expected to follow.
content: The Biden administration will release the highly anticipated details of a federal vaccine mandate for private employers “in coming days,” a representative for the Department of Labor said Monday. When the details become public, a flurry of corporate vaccine mandates is expected to follow.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Penn
title: PG&E says it faces a federal inquiry and $1.15 billion in losses over the Dixie fire.
description: The California utility already faces state criminal charges over the blaze this year, the second largest wildfire ever recorded in the state.
content: Federal investigators are seeking records from Pacific Gas & Electric in connection with a devastating wildfire this year, raising the specter of more charges against the giant California utility.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon LaFraniere
title: A White House official says the Pfizer pediatric vaccination program is set to be ‘at full strength’ next week.
description: “We are planning on some vaccinations towards the end of this week,” said Jeffrey D. Zients, a top White House official, adding that the government will deliver a total of 15 million doses “across the next week or so.”
content: Though several million pediatric doses of Pfizer-BioNTech’s coronavirus vaccine should be available in the next few days, the vaccination program for children aged 5 to 11 in the United States will only start “running at full strength” in the second week of November, a top White House official said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicolas Rapold
title: Talking About ‘Attica,’ the Newest Documentary on the Prison Uprising
description: Fifty years after the fact, the filmmakers Stanley Nelson and Traci A. Curry reflect on the bloody standoff and what it accomplished.
content: On Sept. 9, 1971, hundreds of inmates took over the Attica Correctional Facility near Buffalo to demand better conditions. “Attica,” a new documentary directed by Stanley Nelson and co-directed by Traci A. Curry, recounts the occupation and the massacre that followed on Sept. 13 when armed law enforcement officers stormed the prison and 39 inmates and hostages were killed under sustained police gunfire and tear-gassing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: Democrats’ Bill Would Cover Poor Uninsured Adults, Up to a Point
description: The $1.85 trillion social policy bill would provide free private health insurance for more than two million adults locked out of coverage, but only for four years.
content: ALBANY, Ga. — After giving up on their goal of creating a new Medicaid program to cover two million poor adults, Democrats are aiming to provide them with free private coverage as part of the party’s social policy bill. But there is a catch: The benefits would last only four years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $4.5 Million Homes in California
description: A 1912 Beaux-Arts home in San Francisco, a four-bedroom house in Mill Valley and a penthouse loft in an Art Deco building in Los Angeles.
content: This house is in West Clay Park, a neighborhood that was developed in the 1910s and is known for its stately homes and quiet, tree-lined streets. It has been owned by the same family for 60 years and has been well maintained inside and out. The original molding and wainscoting in many rooms has been preserved, and the grand facade still has its original stucco garlands and a niche with an original statue.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold and Ali Kate Cherkis
title: Subway Scenes: Halloween Returns With a Vengeance
description: Lanternflies, mushrooms and container ships: Costumed riders came back to haunt New York City’s underground during one of the city’s most celebrated holidays.
content: For long stretches of the last year and a half, scenes of New York City’s subway system — a once-bustling underground thoroughfare suddenly plunged into eerie emptiness by the spread of the coronavirus — felt haunting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gross
title: Handball Federation Ends Bikini Bottom Requirement for Women
description: After outrage over a fine levied against the Norwegian women’s beach handball team for competing in shorts, the sport’s international federation said it was changing its rules.
content: The International Handball Federation has updated its rules so that women will no longer be required to play in bikini bottoms, responding to months of pressure from female players and coaches who described the uniform requirements as sexist.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Susan Dominus
title: Huma Abedin Has Been to Hell and Back. Now She’s Gingerly Telling the Tale.
description: “Both/And” may not be the most introspective memoir, but it gives readers a front-row view of heartache and humiliation.
content: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Linwood Holton, 98,Virginia Governor Who Pushed for Racial Equality, Dies
description: The first Republican governor of the state in almost a century, he seemed to herald a new, post-racial South. He later became disillusioned with his own party.
content: A. Linwood Holton Jr., who as Virginia’s first Republican governor in nearly a century knocked loose the stranglehold of white supremacy on the state, cleaned up its waterways and promoted a vision for a biracial Republican coalition across the South, died on Oct. 28 at his home in Kilmarnock, Va. He was 98.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman
title: John Kerry is already looking toward next year to push countries to do more.
description: “Glasgow was never ever going to get every country joining up,” Mr. Kerry said. He’s already looking to next year to build on pledges that nations have made and push them to do more.
content: John Kerry, who helped clinch the Paris climate agreement in 2015 as secretary of state and who came out of retirement to become President Biden’s climate envoy, arrives on Monday with a carefully crafted message for the United Nations summit: It is critically important but not the last chance for action.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brett Berk
title: To Protest Iran’s Anti-Gay Abuses, an Artist Painted a Dictator’s Car
description: “Wherever there is injustice, we need to talk about it,” Alireza Shojaian said.
content: The Paykan was the first car manufactured in Iran. Produced from 1967 to 2015, it started life as a licensed copy of an outmoded British vehicle, the Hillman Hunter, but it nevertheless became a symbol of national pride, priced for middle-class Iranians.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Bosman
title: A Timeline of the Kyle Rittenhouse Shootings and His Trial
description: Here are the events that led to Mr. Rittenhouse, 18, standing trial in the fatal shootings of two men and the wounding of another in Kenosha, Wis.
content: Kyle Rittenhouse, 18, will stand trial this week in the fatal shootings of two men and the wounding of another, the result of a confrontation in Kenosha, Wis., last August.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Bailey
title: Stream These 12 Titles Before They Leave Netflix in November
description: Jack Black, Michael B Jordan, Richard Pryor: A lot of favorites are leaving for U.S. subscribers this month.
content: Two much-loved television series leave Netflix in the United States this November, along with some heartbreaking dramas, “Dad movies,” an Oscar winner for best picture and vehicles for the considerable comic talents of Richard Pryor and Jack Black. Find out about those and more of this month’s catch-them-while-you-can titles, below. (Dates reflect the final day a title is available.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise, Clare Toeniskoetter, Mooj Zadie, Sydney Harper, Larissa Anderson, Mike Benoist, Dan Powell, Elisheba Ittoop, Rachelle Bonja and Chris Wood
title: Why Do So Many Traffic Stops Go Wrong?
description: A Times investigation showed that hundreds of unarmed drivers and passengers died at the hands of the police in recent years.
content: This episode contains strong language and scenes of violence.

author: By Natasha Frost
title: New Zealand Held a Contest for Bird of the Year. The Birds Lost.
description: The long-tailed bat, one of the country’s only two native land mammals, flew away with the top prize.
content: AUCKLAND, New Zealand — The candidates didn’t know they were running. The winner received no prize. And, at least by appearance, the champion appeared to be ineligible to compete.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabe Cohn
title: What’s on TV This Week: ‘The Oratorio’ and ‘Dexter: New Blood’
description: Martin Scorsese hosts an hourlong documentary on PBS. And the serial-killer drama “Dexter” returns to Showtime (with a new subtitle).
content: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, Nov. 1-7. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman
title: Michael Bloomberg announces an effort to shut down coal in 25 countries.
description: Michael R. Bloomberg, the billionaire and former mayor of New York City, intends to announce on Monday an effort to shut down coal in 25 countries.
content: Michael R. Bloomberg, the billionaire and former mayor of New York City, intends to announce on Monday an effort to shut down coal in 25 countries.

title: A Close Look at My Day of the Dead Altar
description: Mexico’s Day of the Dead is one of the country’s most important celebrations, with ofrendas, or altars, to honor loved ones who have died a central tradition. Here’s a look at mine.
content: Mexico’s Day of the Dead is one of the country’s most important celebrations, with ofrendas, or altars, to honor loved ones who have died a central tradition. Here’s a look at mine.

title: What Is a ‘Carbon Footprint’? And 12 Other Climate Buzzwords
description: As climate change discussions take center stage in Glasgow, here’s a primer on some of the jargon you’re likely to hear a lot.

title: Kenneth Branagh Is Finally Processing His Childhood Trauma
description: “I hesitate to use the word … a cardinal sin for my parents was to be suggesting that anything you’d been through was worthy of categorizing in such a way.”
content: “I hesitate to use the word … a cardinal sin for my parents was to be suggesting that anything you’d been through was worthy of categorizing in such a way.”

description: What should you get for all the beloved but quirky, picky, fancy, practical or eccentric people in your life? Let our experts help.

title: How Much Are Countries Pledging to Reduce Emissions?

author: By The Associated Press and Reuters
title: At Least 5 People Are Dead in Nigeria Building Collapse
description: The 21-story apartment building was under construction when it crumbled in Lagos, Nigeria, killing at least five people. Many more people are feared to be trapped under the rubble.
content: The 21-story apartment building was under construction when it crumbled in Lagos, Nigeria, killing at least five people. Many more people are feared to be trapped under the rubble.

author: By Sam Sifton
title: A Special Steak Dinner
description: Take care when plating these steak mock frites and side salad, if only because it’s fun and looks elegant.
content: Good morning. I had a lovely meal the other night at Balthazar, in the SoHo district of Manhattan, folded into a booth with an excellent view of scenesters and tourists, arts-adjacent money people, date-night couples and Gucci-clad birthday groups. Central to my enjoyment of the evening was a salad I think you might try to make at home, using Julia Moskin’s ace recipe for mustard-shallot vinaigrette.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Readers’ Farewell to Nicholas Kristof, ‘One of a Kind’
